subject: Cooking
title: Lobster Was Once Prison Food
description: A short lesson to help you apply Lobster Was Once Prison Food.

hook.text: Lobster at $50 a plate feels luxurious. In colonial America, feeding it to prisoners was considered cruel.

buildup.text: Lobsters were so abundant in New England that they washed ashore in 2-foot piles. Servants ate them daily.

discovery.text: Colonial contracts specified that servants couldn't be forced to eat lobster more than 3 times per week.

twist.text: Railway dining cars in the 1880s served lobster to inland travelers who'd never seen it â€” rebranding it as exotic.

climax.text: Overfishing, scarcity, and clever marketing transformed lobster from trash food to luxury symbol in just 50 years.

punchline.text: Lobster's luxury status was invented. Its prison past was real.

quiz.question: How was lobster viewed in colonial America?
options: As poverty food served to prisoners and servants
